WTT03PP9LK2Vk_Hr0uNCoQ.text: Khans has been around for ages and a mainstay of the Indian cuisine circuit. It was one of the first halal restaurants and thus very popular with the sub-continent community. The décor is a little dated but the food is very very good. All at a reasonable price too. The food is traditional Pakistani/Indian thus you will find all your fav curries there. The tandoori dishes are exceptional and the mango lassi is immense.

O8rC4yywDy4_mSbmQlxwfQ.text: I had heard this place was the Indian version of the Chinese Won Key in China Town - a fun churn them out place with good food.So I wasn't surprised to be greeted by Rude Waiters from the start. However, this is the only entertaining thing about the place. If you think thats entertaining.The food was dire. I'm not sure how they managed to mess up the chutneys and lime sauce (it was salty) but they did. The curries were beyond dire - i've experienced better sauce from the cheapest jar of sauce in a supermarket. I think you even get better curries in most of the states (not known for their curries). They no longer serve Alcohol of any kind - you can't even bring your own to the place, a feature often common with the Indians on Brick Lane.

i5Ow7ckIZa8c6g4-Tnj_mg.text: As this restaurant was recommended to us by good friends, I was quite disappointed when it did not live up to expectations. It was a Sunday night and although busy, our order was taken promptly. The vegetable samosas were fresh, crispy and very tasty. A good start. Then we waited and waited and waited some more. Loads of people who had arrived after us were served their main courses before us. It gave us time to appraise the decor, which is ok, but overall the harsh lighting spoils the atmosphere, making it seem more like a canteen. I had chosen a vegetable biryani which, when it eventually arrived, consisted of unappetisingly tasteless rice with what looked like frozen vegetables through it. These were overcooked too! There was no accompanying tasty sauce, just a dish of raita. I have eaten Indian food all over the country and this was probably the worst dish I have ever been given. The rest of the dishes were not as bad as this and I am left to wonder if this was just a blip.

Ba-7PUKwdAcqtroHAm1zIQ.text: Great food at fantastic value for money JJ

bCDiL8TwfJ3sTdh2lOkfrw.text: a belated posting (finally...UK yelp!) from my honeymoon, 2007. we were on a b-u-d-g-e-t and it didn't help that the dollar's so weak. anyway, a hotel employee recommended this place as a local fave. so yummy, great menu selection, and totally decent prices. it was crowded both times we came here, but that did not affect the attentive customer service. in a cool area with lots of little shops and cafes.  once in awhile i'll lean over to my husband and say "i wish we were at khan's right now". if you like indian food, make sure to hit this spot up.

va2fmmFtI0neUyhNm0axSg.text: Always found this place to be clean and well kept. Staff are friendly and the food is great. Nice to go as a big group as they are very accomodating. Decor is on the tacky side but in a good way as it adds to the atmosphere!

B4oKy_75Mt2CsKsJxHGVTA.text: Really like this place. Its reasonable but delicious food. I always go for butter chicken in this place, the best I have ever had anywhere else. Have it with the buttered nan and its real good. Starters are nice too, go for the mixed grill which comes sizzling. Tandoori is a bit too red for my liking (the type that stains your fingers) and the pina colada mocktail is superb! Used to always make the trip down with uni friends from central london. Can get really packed at times, best time is probably lunch time, to avoid queues. You can always pop round the corner to one of the cafes for some nice dessert afterwards

OGmPqzdTUVEpFhMAmOEVVQ.text: This Indian restaurant has received so many awards for its top quality food and excellent service, and even though their fame keeps growing, their prices stay low and dependable. The restaurant is massive, with an upstairs and downstairs seating area. There are lots of tables and there isn't anything noticable about the way the place is decorated. However, one thing stands out, and that is the exceptionally buzzing atmosphere. The place is full of a huge variety of people enjoying good food and good company. The dishes are familiar, but, when they arrive, they taste fresh and unique, with a special spin put on each and every dish. This place is great to go with a large group of people so that you can all share and enjoy the good food together.

3mRPJ2De8J-d_xrGd28akw.text: Very popular, extremely cheap Indian restaurant, serving really authentic cuisine in good size portions. If you want an authentic Indian dining experience in this popular spot with good atmosphere, then this is the place. As they mention, they don't serve Alcohol, but the alcohol free Cobra is ok, and the food more than makes up for the potential short coming.

hOGYR4RD_tAybk0I9lBEIw.text: I had gone to Khan's for an early dinner on a sunday (we probably stopped here because we were too tired to walk in the cold to Urban Turban) ... and i left disappointed. On reading the reviews here, i can better appreciate this place as the expectations aren't mismatched any more.Now Westbourne grove is my favourite street in London in terms of food. You have so many good restaurants serving a variety of cuisines. I have had very good experiences in most of them ... not so here.Don't get me wrong ... the food is good. The thali here is probably one of the best value you can get for Indian meals in Zone 1. For less than £11 you can get rice, 2 curries, papad, a starter and a huge naan. They taste pretty good too. But the service is shabby to say the least. So much so that after i had finally paid by credit card, the server came and left the card on top of some gravy that had fallen on the table cloth. In spite of the good food, i left with a bitter after-taste.Yes, the food is good and cheap ... and would have surely been a regular destination for me in my student days ... but not any more.

l0vsxCyaHwkF2rSGOCBpJw.text: After a day of photography under dreary skies, my dramatic portrait photography group needed a location to share shots and refuel. The main meals at Khan's Restaurant start at £5.15 per dish with the usual naan and rice options to order separately. I ordered a staple chicken korma, pilau rice and bottled water. While a korma may be a not-so-adventurous choice it is generally a good gauge to the quality of an Indian restaurant. The patient service soon began to lack, our orders were scattered around the table without being announced and left me serving dollops of paneer onto my bed of rice before realize it all smelled wrong. The food itself was satisfactory and served the purpose of filling my stomach void but there is nothing fabulous to report. The flavour lacked lustre and was without that special touch.The single bill kept mobile calculators at hand and they were slow to deal with debit card payment.  While Khan's won't be making the cut for my repeat visit list, the good company made the experience not all-in-all bad.

YOFM_KJU0rKov4Uul3XtLw.text: Got in here without a reso on a Friday night, although it was VERY busy!  Service was a bit slow, but not too bad considering how many people were there.  The food was excellent, and the non-alcoholic drink menu was fun.  We had Chicken Tikki Masala, fried rice, and some kind of spinach potato dish. All very good!

mH3xmolQ__0nNiv-GvAxUQ.text: My brother and I went to Khan based on a recommendation at our hotel after a nice day of sightseeing.  Khan is not a fancy place.  Food was decent, service was ok.  Overall a decent experience.  I may go back again to give it a second chance the next time I am in London.

1IETDGkjtsl_sMClEZWb8Q.text: The food here is absolutely incredible... the best indian I have ever eaten. We had lamb biryani, rojan josh, butter chicken and some naans. They were magic for our tastebuds - not oily, plenty of meat, rice with deep flavor. And inexpensive!! So why 4 stars... average waiter service with few smiles to customers (one wonders whether a smile would crack the face of the smiler)... no booze. No liquor license no booze... so food that is 6 stars with 2 star waiter service and 1 star no booze... take out and have your drinks with this king's meal at home!

gQnOTy3xEpVp-DPxEbahXA.text: This place has fantastic Indian food without any frills. The restaurant itself is very outdated... I doubt they've made a change to the inside since the 1970's but that certainly doesn't affect the food. The restaurant is quite large with dining rooms on both the ground level and in the basement. The walls are painted with desert and palm tree murals which adds to the outdated yet wonderful tackyness of the place. The food here is absolutely what makes a trip here worthwhile though. They've got an extensive menu of traditional Indian options. The portions are small enough that you can get a few dishes and share them if you're with a group. Among my favorites are the chicken tikka masala, the lamb tikka biryani (yum yum yum) and the sag. Their mango lassie is also delicious!

fg_lY5buX9AbXRkGnzEDpg.text: This place is inexpensive, and that's about it. The food is at best mediocre, and the samosas were the most greasy and bland we've ever had. The service was spotty at best, and we had to stand up and start to leave to get any. With all the nice Indian restaurants in London, why waste your  time, avoid this place and you'll be better off.

jwU-QB8fHbg9FZmJfUTN_A.text: I remember back in the day when Kahn's was amazing. It was the best Indian in all of London. I wouldn't say that it is that good anymore, but I wouldn't turn down a meal there either!

x4528_cY4wcyNBwaSESccQ.text: Khans used to be a legend and often visited by my colleagues and I once upon a time almost 15 years ago. I visited it again today (July 2012)  and was not disappointed because I knew what to expect; not much had changed! Still the same fast paced hustly bustly type indian restaurant  unique in its own way. Food was not too bad and has its own touch.. Its alright for a decent inexpensive meal but certainly not a fine dining experience.

fO1DR0U-kyrfjm8lcAGYvQ.text: I've come to loathe this place! Dragged here on too many occassions to eat toxic looking sauces, strange textured meat, abrupt staff and random delivery of dishes. Go to the nearby durbar it is soooo much better!

InwiFgkC1XxaMwhitI-g5A.text: Let me just say in comparison to anything I've had in NY (Bricklane, Minar) Khans is very good Indian style curry. Tandoori chicken was moist and well seasoned. Both the seafood and lamb curries were flavourful but my complaint is the sauce was indistinguishable. Lots of food and for 3 people dinner was 38L with drinks - pretty reasonable for London.

Mki5NDskSkLX9xveaMV0-w.text: I love Indian and I live near queesway, so it's safe to assume I hv visited most of the Indian places in the vicinity including khan's - the food unfortunately fails to inspire and other than the fact that it's big and costs less , there is nothing else which will remind me of this place . If u want ok curry food at a cheap price, this is the place . However if u want more authentic Indian food , try the masala zone at bayswater or better stillat earl's court. The Bengal is pretty good too

QNiL4go4uCUFKm7465LicA.text: Easy, quick dinner in London while on business. Very good food and I would definitely go back if I was in the area again

7EbKK00m7ZzFr4M--pnNGQ.text: I think this was the first curry joint that I visited when I moved to London in 2001. I remember being mildly impressed but wondering so, what's all the fuss about how great the Indian food is in Britain? I've since had meals at other South Asian restaurants that knocked my socks off. A nice thing about Khan's is the gorgeous murals on the walls. I also remember the service to be exceptional (which at the time I didn't realize just how exceptional good service is in this country!). All in all, I'd say it's a good one to keep in mind. If I lived nearby I'd probably go there from time to time (I think they do takeaway too). It's definitely worth a try if only to admire the pretty paintings on the walls.

UZNlYPgYoxEHiILA4beeAQ.text: I used to live across the road from Khan's, and still to today continue to go back there for meals. If possible try to sit in the front portion of the restaurant as this is the nicer area, with it's great interior of artificial palm trees and a painted sky. The menu is massive, and every dish (that I have so far tried) is excellent.

3KJDVSzCNm9pHWbMEM3cGA.text: Great Indian!This is one of my favourite Indian haunts in London. I went 20 years ago as a student and then visited it again last year on a Sunday lunchtime and recalled how good it was. I have since been back afew times however, maybe its my age.but I do prefer it at lunchtime/early evening rather than a Friday / saturday night. That's when the waiters do become slightly rude and more harassed!The food is great - good Indian cuisine - I like the biryiani's - great sauces. Do remember it doesn't serve alcohol, however there is a good pub on the corber for a few drinks before hand! You seeperfect Sunday afternoon!Great value too!

F8bhbeiH29wRL2V-4ra4rA.text: Khans has more of a following because of their name than anything else.The staff's attitude is as if they are doing you a favour. It is a nice large venue in case you are a big group or having a function. The view of all the dirty dishes while eating your meal isn't the greatest one. The food isn't bad but more attention could be paid to service, decor and general cleanliness. The best thing that they have going for them is their location. I would rather go to a place in Whitechapel like Lahori Kebab House or Tayyabs any day.

4I0lgsjrOpxMovKAAXwpbg.text: this is a canteen type restaurant do not expect anything spectacular, the food is great and needs to be sampled. try the butter chicken you will not be dissapointed!

Qcn4QyJl46ZbkAQQfsWwWA.text: Great food, noisy, hurried average service, tips include, alcohol free, fantastic value for money. Go and eat here at least once in your life.Keema nan is to die for.

IKFQu5BI9pTwlKpnpPUCmQ.text: I do not know what is going on here with the reviews... but this place is absolutely the best."If you haven't been to Khan's, you haven't been to London" might seem a bit pretentious, but it rings true to me.I absolutely love the food... their korma is the best I have ever had, and their naan is always deliciously crispy, and their mango lassie is so refreshing.It has gotten more expensive over the years, but it is still amazing value, and is a destination in an already amazing city.

N650Uaw9ooTjx8qm8MEoBw.text: While serving three weeks in the US Naval Reserve I had the privilege and honor of taking up residence at the Thistle hotel near Hyde Park. As a connoisseur of curries, I thought I would see what the London had to offer. The offerings were plentiful. Where I come form there is a bar on every street corner. In London there is also a bar on every street corner -- and a Tandoori Restaurant. I stumbled across Kahn's because I was feeling nostalgic for a little apartment I stayed at when I was a kid about 16 years prior. Nearby Queenways Station was/is a cornucopia of ethic diversity - a Catholic Church was sandwiched between a donar kebab stand and curry house. A little further up street was a pedestrian mall and....Khans. The nice thing about Khan's from what I recall was the affordability.  You could easily spend 50 quid for a dinner out in London, but Khan's was perhaps half that price. Of course, I had the Chicken Tikka Masala which was a mouth watering feast of spicy succulence. Wash that down with a King Fisher and little nan bread, you have just had a quintessential London "ruby."I highly recommend it. Just wish I could snap my fingers and be in the dining room.

_tYu65ZU0VNeZMcYMx8Gcg.text: Khans Indian restaurant in Westbourne Grove is quite an eccentric place. The restaurant is spread across one quite large room with a bar at the right hand side. The whole restaurant has a slightly kitsch Indian theme which means pretend palm tree pillars, and a faux rattan pagodas mixed with well done desert scape and traditional scene murals on the walls. The overall effect is like the dining room of a pretend Indian palace at a dated theme park. The food is a range of Indian standards. I went with a friend and we both had a thali and a lassi, which were both well done and very good value. A charmingly decorated restaurant the serves inexpensive, well done Indian culinary standards.

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom

ekANErjb4hEk8G9pNUWi6w.text: Khan's was always known as a cheap place for students on a budget to get a curry. My university digs were just down the road in Notting Hill Gate and I made a few trips here over the years.One amusing episode was when our group was told that it would be a long time for a table until the waiter spotted an expensive property magazine in my hand, which I had just picked up on the way out. Funnily, we were seated pretty quicklyI returned here recently for old times sake. I noted the prices had risen but still not too high. I think my palate may have matured since 'student with no money' days but the flavours were only average.So overall, 3 stars for feeding me cheaply over the years!

3syI47_cwPrBo5r-Y1McBw.text: One of the best indian restaurants in London for sure. They do not serve alcohol here but you can bring your own.The biryani's are excellent. The mutton curry is delicious. They have a very large, diverse menu. Always a joy to eat here.

5RHgE5Bab7yckEBbAMVB0g.text: Don't compare the food here with other Indian restaurants. The entrees are around 5 - 7 GBP. Service can be unpredictable, sometimes impeccable and sometimes downright annoying. The nan is always served warm and is pretty good. Dishes that you can't go wrong ordering are the  butter chicken, tandoori chicken, tandoori chops and the sheek kebabs. The Biryani here on a scale of 1 - 10,  gets a 2.The dessert  menu is not much to write about.the Gulab Jamun tastes like it is out of a can.If you are looking for cheap, mediocre food and service this is the place.

qbVvGTgKQaqId7ZbRb2JFw.text: A very nice location and very good food at a very good price.You can have a meal here for about GBP 5  7,- and the food is really good Indian food with very nice Indian drinks.

3QE5uJBAUfIce1KScAdNbA.text: I think it's important to review a place within a context. So those comparing this place to other Indian/Pakistani establishments which serve main courses at 10-12quid per, are being unfair to both sorts of establishments. I compare this inexpensive foodjoint to other similarly cheap and cheerful spots and find it satisfies quite well for those days when you're feeling broke and feel like some greasy but delish curry. Their maincourses are priced at levels which can only be matched by take-away food, if at all. The decor and the size of the place screams of the stereotypical curry houses with cut-out ethnic decor and faux exotic images. I have to admit that this is not the sort of place I would pick to go to on a night out - I've become somewhat averse to greasy curry unless I'm drunk. But a Siberian friend was in town and wanted some Indian curry, London style, and thus we ended up here. Service was passable, didn't annoy but didn't delight either. The menu had a wide range of offerings and looking at how inexpensive the dishes were, I assumed the portion sizes would be small, and we ended up over-ordering some. Nothing terribly distinctive about the food - it was spicy, a bit greasy and served in ample proportions, regular Indian fare. It was tasty and made in conventional ways - don't expect cool fusion dishes or anything overly experimental here.  Nothing was unbearably hot for my Siberian friend, who has low-ish spice tolerance; he was well pleased about partaking in a quintessentially Londonesque meal. I would recommend this place as an OK place to stop by if you're in the area and looking for a cheap option... I don't imagine going out of the way to eat here, but nothing about it makes me want to avoid it either.

Xjl3BV_HQ2oKK-kh-B3f9g.text: Initially my companions and I felt ignored. The waitstaff did not acknowledge us for quite some time. Ultimately though we had a fantastic meal that would have me visiting often.

LR0w2IgZCTT1Gb9RW6vqPQ.text: I've been going to Khan's since it opened. There was a period about 10 years ago when the quality dropped, but now it's pretty damn good again.Basically it's all about the Butter Chicken, which is to my taste the best in the known Universe. And I've had a few.Unbelievable.Peshwari naan & muttar paneer also great.I can understand that some people don't like the staff, though I find them ok.Also the few times where I've tried random stuff from the menu I have been dissapointed, so perhaps it's not all great.Stick with the chef's recommendations, that's what they do best.; )

yjP0UYOjkttjXYxdcYKePA.text: Hmmm ... good food.I thought their butter chicken was waayyyy too oily and had wayyy too much cream in it. Their saag alu ( spinach with potatoes ) was also wayyy too oily. I also had their Methi chicken ....  It was good. The weird things was, their butter chicken and their Methi Chicken seemed to have the very same base spice. It is not quite supposed to be like that.This place is alright ....  It was an enjoyable experience. On the other hand I have had much better Pakistani / Indian food than this.

Aj8qf3rMHFBHi_7nsH9V1g.text: Good food, quick and effective service.  They don't do all things great, though - this won't compare to Lahore Kebab House or Tayyab's for things like Lamb Chops/Shikh Kebabs/Nihari - but they do have fantastic curries.  Another reviewer said their portions here were huge; I disagree, i think their portions are actually on the smaller side.  But this is my go-to Indian place for things like Madras, Tikka Massala, etc.  If Northern grill-type food is what you're after, go to LKH instead.  But for your curries, this is one of the best.  And they deliver.

0TYAqVZ4lP5gxQ8lLojhYg.text: when oZo is in London we always hit this spot! The Chicken Jalfezi is JalCrazy good!!! My band has even wrote songs bout this place.. Here's a funny story bout this spot... One time oZo was eating here and we told the Waiter that the food was "crazy good" . He thought that we were calling him crazy ... So he tripped out and started yelling at us "CRAZY? I'LL SHOW YOU CRAZY" !!! Just a lil miss communication. We are yanks!  Anyways ... For the longest time after this we started say "I'm bout to go Jalfezi on that ass" in honor of our waiter.

JXuCFZBrothCwTvhkiI_lQ.text: I have lived in Bayswater all my life and I often read about Khans in magazines or heard people saying it was cheap. So I gave it a go..never again! The waiters were unfriendly, the space was cramped, the naan tasted stale, my soft drink tasted cheap and flat and the curry was one of the most disappointing ones I've ever tasted in a restaurant. To top it off it was no cheaper than any other indian restaurant. Don't waste your time here, try the Bengal on Porchester road - now that is good!!!!

Wm39qFARPy6vnHJuE8RL6w.text: I will not waste my time and money going to this restaurant again. I went there today for dinner,  hoping for a real Pakistani meal. But what a disappointed it was. I ordered  mutton biryani , chicken masala and chicken korma. mutton biryani was OK. however ever chicken masala and korma tasted like crap. I will not go back to this restaurant.

3AYKeUPY0EiMCwR9lt4BMQ.text: Great food, good variety. Do not miss the butter chicken here together with the prawn biriyani. Service was not great hence the 4 star rating. Overall, affordable and great food!

cPwGle07cTfwJgmJVF6N9Q.text: Crowded, loud, rushed.....and excellent food. There is some serious heat in the spicy dishes here, and the waiters really don't want to hear you fumble through what you "think you might want" to eat. Come in, sit down, order, eat, and leave. Highly recommended, but not for those who are sensitive to a bit of chaos.

6cVrjGK3FdVeGjo5BZ517w.text: Located along Westbourne Grove, Khans is a cheap, and reasonably tasting Indian restaurant. I always seems to pay just around £10 and come out feeling stuffed with a curry, vegetables, rice or naan and a drink filling me up. Alcohol is not allowed in this restaurant so enjoy some of their other unusual drinks (mocktail mixtures) or one of their tasty lassi mixtures. Sometimes you have to wait for a table but it's not unusual that you get seated immediately since they have a lot of people and things seem to flow very quickly. Some of the waiters help this along by sometimes being a little bit pushy but when you're paying such a small amount, it's understandable.

Arm82u0bVP8jPjBDx8f-lg.text: This is one of my first meals if I am in London.  The service is good.  The prices are reasonable.  The food is stellar!!

7hF2dPBeUeowz_eUJscZiQ.text: I had the okra and the butter chicken. The okra was just a horrible mash (okra was not fresh and very bland) and the butter chicken was cold. The mango lassie was delicious. Unfortunately, I was very sick afterwards. No proof it was khans but timing matches (dinner vs 2am issues)

jQyercw90vZYlnRQPUTnjw.text: This place was a lot better several years ago.  Either the quality has gone down OR my tastebuds have upped their snobbery game.  Pretty disappointed in the food.  Service was OK.

7GrIpxF1CDjsxKXfOuyx8g.text: I live in Hollywood, CA but Kahn's is one of the places i sometimes miss when I'm over here. I recall these rainy winters in London when all you can think about is comfort food. Kahn's has very good Dall a lentil soup, and the lamb korma was delicious, and the sag aloo, the mango lassi and the rose lassi. The place is nothing special but it's always there, always delicious. Love it

pP-remnvJFOpE0JOPHVgEg.text: Great food and great service. I ordered the chicken tikka masala with garlic naan and rice. All delicious. Also the chocolate shake was perfection.

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom

chlk7wALiWy0BUhAnvNOLQ.text: Be careful with the lunch-time pricing: £9.50 for the limited-choice all-you-can-eat buffet; or £4.50 for the 1-item special lunch menu. Their confusing signs can be tricky. Next time I'll do the a-la-carte instead of the buffet, which was not as good as other's: one of the chicken choices was cold - it's burner was off until I told the waiter. Service is OK - except for the many dirty glasses. Tired decor - place has gone downhill a bit.

-742bDVgQ7_d00y_mdMcZg.text: Been there thrice! Always have a lovely time. They're quick and the food is always delicious and pipin' hot. Gotta be careful to check how spicy your meal is going to be though! Because, I can stand heat but not a whole meal's worth.  The lassies are great but a bit heavy after a meal. You'll be better off with a nice glass of fresh juice. I know I am! I've noticed that the food is always more than we can handle. I wouldn't order a seperate dish of rice for each person, for example; three for four is more than enough. I've never tried any of the deserts there but I wasn't tempted much, to be honest. Overall, this is a great place for friends and family alike. Larger groups will not feel out of place at all! This will always be a place I recommend to friends and family.

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Niiiiiice
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Faluda

foFS-d4g-3SxVJmPilAvMg.text: The food is delicious and not as greasy and oily as we are used to which is great!! On the back side of the menu there was a healthy options menu that could accord ate for many type of allergies. The service however was not great. There were many people walking around but only one could take our order. They were all Indian as far as we could tell and some were harder to understand than others but it was a little difficult to hear. Sometime when we would ask for something they would say yes yes and walk away quickly and then just stand in one spot and look around. Eventually we would get what we wanted but it took too long.

2eLpD-PmLM4r8lkjtUBAIQ.text: The best Indian restaurant in London by far, especially this branch. Totally recommend lambs biryani.

lKb2ZqoL0xtrTm27AFr4Sg.text: I would give them 4 star after I went there repeatedly. Their food is great (seekh kebab, methi gosht, roti etc) or at least good/not bad (biryani, chicken karahi). Restaurant is relatively large and I would say reasonably clean compared to ethnic places. Downside: service is not great, waiters do the job just coz they have to earn money, they certainly don't want to serve. Only radon for my 4 is their good-to-great food. Advice: try to go off the peak hours

bO3rIE5rwCWwUGM8V4IVVQ.text: In many ways a London institution, it seems like everyone has heard and been to Khans. Not the prettiest place, and even a bit kitschy, but it serves all the fan favorite Indian dishes. Fancy a curry, this is the place to go for easy going fare. Great for groups.

ND7goWLHpUnAnJQz5qQ5ag.text: Delish!This would be my go-to choice for Indian food any day in London.  Friendly service, delicious food, good prices.It's not a high end place by any means, so if you're looking for someplace with more ambiance, Khan's isn't the right stop.  But if you're craving some delicious Indian food, this is the place to go.The portions are also huge, so you'll guaranteed have leftovers for lunch the next few days after visiting Khan's.  Bonus!!

IwT2nAaBZi0mOZJMkjNxlw.text: Excellent place just hidden round the corner at the end of Bayswater Street. Its a massive restaurant inside, with a weird sky-blue ceiling and palm trees painted on the wall, but the main attraction here is the food, which is also extremely good value for money. If you're looking for a posh, high end Indian restaurant to entertain business clients, this is not for you. But if you're looking for a filling, delicious cheap meal, then this is perfect. Khans is also halal, does not serve pork or beef at all, with all their meat either seafood, lamb, or chicken. They do have a wide variety of vegetarian dishes as well.

wrYw5E4C7f7Qa3K9WOI5TA.text: I heard a lot about this place, worked around the corner for 3 years and only went on my very last day in the job. Honestly, not all it was cracked up to be. The service was pretty crappy, generally barked at by the waiters and certainly gave off that Basil Fawlty feeling: that customers were getting in the way of them doing their job...The food was decent, nothing really to write home about but tasty and definitely plenty of it. Important note, this restaurant does not serve alcohol, so no beer with that spicey Dhal I'm afraid...

MtKsfFKllsxFyqvnNjiTlg.text: Now this is the real deal when it comes to Indian food, environment wasn't so great but the food made up for it :)

WGq84heQog6IF5UCDJvpPg.text: Khan's of Bayswater a bit like that Star Trek film it's named after - The Wrath Of Khan. It started out with good intentions, hoping to save the world with tasty food. Unfortunately somewhere along the way it became a genetically modified super evil villain that wanted nothing more than to destroy captain Kirk. The last few times I've been there it's been getting worse and worse, and last time was the last straw. I don't want to go there again. The food was rubbish and the bill was expensive. The service sucked and the cutlery was dirty. Once the producer of the best butter chicken in the universe, Khan's is now running on impulse power compared to the warp speed of Tayyab's, Mirch Masala and Raavi's.

j_UmrN1Z-TuA2pGWRZRMdw.text: So the service was pretty ordinary here.  I felt at times during the night the wait staff were trying to hurry us out of the store.  The food however was delicious.  I enjoyed the food itself and would probably go back there again.

0phwJWrzgGSrFEku80-hkA.text: I force my husband to eat here every time we visit London.  I'll never admit to him it's not the best...but it is my favourite.The service is hit-or-miss, especially if you get seated downstairs or in the backroom.  It may help if you buy a t-shirt...but I've never seen anyone actually make a purchase.But the food is consistent.  My standard is the sag chicken and plain naan.

BpntrZSVSRJVfwjAZCeNmA.text: We got take out from here a couple of times for dinner.  Everything was delicious.  Lamb curry, butter chicken, nan, all were great.  Prices not bad.

vru6ajex247gKzpmUh-3gg.text: Golden oldie. Food is served fast. But the food is not so fresh. Curries are clearly made with powders, not fresh peppers. Kinda mweh.

0Pyyg95HZy5TvT-_tEoIeQ.text: Visited for the first and last time on Saturday. This was an old Uni haunt of my girlfriend. I can see how the reasonable prices (for the location), decent portions (though smaller than my local takeaway), and informal atmosphere would appeal to students as well as anyone else wanting a low key meal out.The service was acceptable (though they forgot our tapwater). We greatly appreciated the fact they validated our parking.However, while we wanted  to enjoy this, bottom line is, the food was frankly poor. Both our currys were so spicy they we couldn't really taste the food properly. Even my korma was hot, I couldn't taste the coconut at all. I must admit I don't like very spicy food so this immediately killed it for me but my girlfriend was raised on it and felt the same about hers. The rice was ok but the naan was very oily and not very soft - overall below the standard of my local takeaways. I will leave this place for the students and tourists in future.

AGwddYkgrDy9HvKMHqWQXA.text: Ok, so I must confess I have been coming to Khans since before some Yelpers were born! I used to live across the road from the damn place which made avoiding it almost impossible (I didn't try). For those new to this place it is an institution. Just around the corner from Queensway it is packed almost all the time. It has a front section which is the nice end of the restaurant with restful palm trees and a nice faux sky painted on the ceiling (try and sit in here if you can). The interior section is darker. It tends to be where large groups (of which there are tons) tend to go. Try not to get sat near the serving hatch at the back where the dirty plates are shoved as the clattering of plates is a bit jarring.The other thing to note about Khans is that it isn't at all about relaxed dining. Given the numbers it is get in get food and get out (think Wong Kei in the 1980s but nowhere near as bad). No lingering over polite conversation and a mango Kulfi. Sure, they have desert and the staff don't rush you but it's important to note if you want lots of time best to go elsewhere. But don't (go elsewhere). Go to Khans. The food-oh the food. I have been eating Indian food for 30+ years and can find no restaurant that can cook food of this quality in such numbers and consistently year in year out. We don't tend to have starters given that we aren't interested in elongating the dining. If we do, then we'll have a chicken tikka which is moist and not overly reddened by food colouring. It looks natural and tastes it. We always have the same mains-chicken tikka masala (really creamy and tender pieces of chicken-mildy spiced and perfectly balanced); chicken jalfrazi (this is not for amateurs-it's basically a sauce which consists of minced green chillis-tart, acidic, deep, hot, spicy and hot (again). It's not for the faint-hearted but I have had no dish anywhere like it. Try it-you won't regret it (actually you might but only because of the heat).Final point -Khans is booze free. I'm not sure if this is because it is a Pakistani owned restaurant or because they had too many problems with drunks. I do recall almost getting into a fight with a drunk in there one night who insisted on talking very loudly about his recent dysentery-like symptoms, so maybe it was the latter. Anyway, they do Cobra alcohol free and the Redan Tavern on the corner of Westbourne Grove and Queensway is a fine first stop. Enjoy.

Q_in4sJcReUaioa6IUdm_g.text: I had higher expectations for the food. I orderd chicken tikka masala and it was okay, i had better before. I also got a falooda and i really liked that but it was also quite expensive (compared to us food prices). Halal food!

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Falooda was delicious but pricy.
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tikka masala with naan.

m-AonDSijnurNZTf9lLOQg.text: Very long wait for sub par food. My husband and I waited an absurdly long time for our orders while others around us received their food in a timely fashion. They are only getting 2 stars because the experience initially started off good with drinks and appetizers, but after that we never saw our server again...LITERALLY. It was as though our server left shortly after taking our order and no one was ever identified to replace him in taking care of our table.

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom

5PlPuQ4oZYPAOXX0eBmJWg.text: Trassssh. Im from Cali but ya boy been in Lil India & Pakistani food and this place was horrendous. The waiter was rude and just cold. The food itself was a joke they brought two small ass samosas and the plates were tiny. On top of that the CURRY WAS SWEET. Who makes sweet chicken tikka? The price was the real cherry on top. 90$ for this trash. Woudlnt recommend to anyone

1B0DFoloOcE7KQr9vL3s1g.text: Rather bland food and the restaurant itself was pretty hot. However service was good. I got the butter chicken and the daal (this was actually pretty tasty)

tQ67BT-ut4Xga9ewvFfD-A.text: Definitely not the same place that I remembered 9 years ago.  The food doesn't taste very good.  Ordered a Chicken Tikka Massala and a Chicken Korma.  The sauces were on point, however the meat was dry and flavorless.  The meat is not marinated, just grilled chicken dumped in sauce.The place is very busy which I am used to, but the service is very impersonal.  You can tell that they just want you to sit, eat and get out so that the table can be free for people waiting.Very disappointing return.

Jt_dXe3KGD7HqNjSX4xh0g.text: Been coming here for years, it never has disappointed. The buffet lunch is under £10 for all you can eat, a huge deal for Central London, and boy it's delicious!  You can't miss this if you're in London.

XtmD7kt1lohEfHMKSHW4eA.text: What a disappointment . The curries were sweet the naan came out cold. The service was a complete mess and we were seated in this corner which was incredibly noisy. Wouldn't recommend - there are much better curries to be had in London!

NpWLgNRda5znme6bzw_a7g.text: Food tastes delicious, We had Veggie Thalia, veggie Korma and butter chicken- very tasty and good value for money.Location is loud, busy, smelly. Better take home.

tyagJUqs4SdROFwM_4wkTQ.text: Now I have been to many Pakistani/Indian restaurants in the US. A popular one in Southern California would be Shalimar, also located in Las Vegas, NV and San Francisco, CA. This place is absolutely the best of the best when it comes to Pakistani cuisine. It has good portions, great taste and the ambiance is nice. I loved visiting London and I was very excited to try the exotic cuisines they have there and this one hit the mark. I was staying near Hyde Park so this was a nice walk for me. If you need to try a great South Asian Halal restaurant this one is the one. Since I have previously worked at restaurants and managed them one problem I always encounter is the portion.  They have such small portions and it's so damn pricey. I wish this wasn't the case. But Khan's managed to give you a good portion and stayed on point for taste. Thank you for doing that, I appreciate it.

1eOPn71rcCL10caqkQMUnA.text: This was the best meal we had while in London! British pub food is just ok, so if you want a great meal go find an Indian restaurant! We ordered Chicken Tikka Masala, which was super delicious especially with the Garlic Naan! We had an order of this ground lamb dish that came on a sizzling plate, that was also fantastic. We also ordered this amazing rice dish that has meat in it. It was beautifully spiced and absolutely delicious (I am craving it right now)! The Mango Lassi went perfectly with the meal. The servers are nice and the food comes out quickly.

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. The best dish we had in London!!!!
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Garlic Naan
Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom

KAympWdGWWpqvBYt0RVRwg.text: I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala with Palau rice and naan.  It was served in under five minutes and everything was served hot.  Chicken could have used some more spicy heat but was otherwise very tasty.  Naan was soft and just a tad chewy...in other words perfect.  Accompanied by an ice cold Diet Coke which is always right!  Servers were attentive.  Nice place.

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Tikka Masala, Palau rice and naan.

gQGVH4p8iL6RjQUARW9Jkw.text: Returning to London after 7 years, and the quality of the food is still great. Service is also good nowadays. Going back one more time with friends before heading back to the States.

5NvivDu61-slirtWe9uNog.text: I came from San Diego, CA to visit London with my family. I had an absolutely wonderful time staying in the Hyde Park area and exploring one of the most historic and popular cities of the world. Having a Pakistani background, my family and I had to try this restaurant. We ordered the usual for a desi person: biryani, chicken tikka, saag, butter chicken, and naan. Everything was delicious. We were amazed at the quality, taste, and presentation the food had. In the west coast of the U.S., we do have a few popular Pakistani restaurants such as Shalimar, Shahnawaz, Al-watan, Noorani, Tandoori Fresh and many others. Each of these have their own tastes and masalas that lead to their deliciousness, but when I came to Khan's I noticed something else that was in our favor. The portions. Perfectly sized portions for families were what got us to love this place. I really appreciate when business owners keep the customers in mind and have reasonable portions. If you go to Bombay Masala in New York City, you get the smallest portions, for the largest price tag. That place wasn't even tasty, and the whole tip process was a mess. So if you are ever in London and knowing about the large Pakistani population there, I'm sure you would like to give the cuisine a try. Khan's is the place to go. Thanks for the wonderful ambiance and food.

HvJFNedPCOpVIrScFCnzKA.text: There food sucks. I went to the manager and told him and he ignored me. A Member of my family had food poisoning. I recommend no one eats here.

2VK9rSxjJTcP82u6Zy1ONg.text: The only good thing is the cola here.Tikka masala is under cooked. Lamb in the biryani is very difficult to cut or eat. It was fibrous and elastic!

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. Supposed to be tikka masala!

JErFywZShJ2SG37ZnxBQjQ.text: You know what! have them... have them all. Yes 5 stars! because.... plenty of space inside, quick service, not fancy, not trying to be something it's not, it's a tad dark and fu!k me it's dated from inside but the food is great... from the curry to biryani, to the lassi to the parathas.FYI no alcohol and you WILL stink for the rest of the day! I PROMISE!See pics :)

photos.caption: Photo of Khan's - London, United Kingdom. great curry.... got nuts!

mD8KUmE-3beFBoQPN5l8LQ.text: The Family I was staying with recommended this place, it's been open for many many years and it's still doing well. It was very good and the staff were very nice and attentive! I had the chutneys then the chicken jalfrezi along with the raita yogurt and some rice and Naan bread. Jalfrezi wasn't overwhelmingly spicy, yogurt and naan help balance the spice level (recommended for those who are sensitive to spicy foods). One of the best Indian places I've been to.

SrJu_td1HFZ3u_jMvcbCUw.text: Every time I visit London, a visit to Khan's is simply a must. The best Indian restaurant I have been to.

3hpCBm5cwfazl6Xz-laZpg.text: India!  Flavours as complex and intriguing as its politics. People.  Lots of them!  Dust.  A lot of that too.  Or khans, which reminds that there was Indian food, plastic furniture and decorating in the 1950s.
